intro: Scopolia trichotoma, commonly known as the hairy scopolia, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its tuberous roots and clusters of fragrant, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and has finely hairy stems and leaves. Its flowers are usually white or pale blue, and it produces small, dark berries that are toxic to humans and animals. Scopolia trichotoma is valued for its ornamental appeal and has historical uses in traditional medicine.
